content:
The provided code chunk demonstrates how to create and apply clip planes in Panda3D using C++ and Python. It includes examples for defining a plane node, attaching it to the scene graph, enabling debugging, and setting up multiple clip planes to affect a teapot model.

This is part of an example showing how to set up and use clip planes to control rendering visibility in 3D scenes.

cpp

LPlane plane(0, 0, 1, -2);
PT(PlaneNode) plane_node = new PlaneNode("plane", plane);
NodePath plane_np = render.attach_new_node(plane_node);

To see a debug representation of the plane, call ~.NodePath.show() on the resulting node path.

Finally, we can use ~.NodePath.set_clip_plane() in order to apply it to any node on which the clipping should take effect:

python

render.setClipPlane(plane_np)

cpp

render.set_clip_plane(plane_np);

Internally, this will create a .ClipPlaneAttrib and assign it to the node's render state.

python

This is a complete sample program showing a teapot that is being affected by two clip planes:

from direct.showbase.ShowBase import ShowBase
from panda3d.core import *

base = ShowBase()

teapot = loader.loadModel("models/teapot")
teapot.setScale(10)
teapot.reparentTo(render)

plane1 = Plane((0, 0, 1), (0, 0, 5))
plane1_np = render.attachNewNode(PlaneNode("plane1", plane1))
plane1_np.show()
teapot.setClipPlane(plane1_np)
